questions.text: A 24-year-old man after drinking too much alcohol developed chest pain. X-ray showed pneumomediastinum. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Esophageal perforation

 

Esophageal perforation is a serious condition that can occur spontaneously, often after episodes of severe vomiting or retching, commonly associated with excessive alcohol consumption. This condition can lead to the presence of air in the mediastinum (pneumomediastinum), which can be detected on an X-ray. The classic clinical presentation includes chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema. When the perforation occurs spontaneously, it is known as Boerhaave syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mallory Weiss syndrome: This condition involves a partial tear at the gastroesophageal junction, usually following severe vomiting. It typically presents with hematemesis (vomiting blood) but does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Pulsion diverticulum: This type of diverticulum is an outpouching of the esophageal wall due to increased intraluminal pressure. While it can cause dysphagia and regurgitation, it does not typically present with pneumomediastinum.

 

Option D. Acute Pericarditis: Acute pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium and typically presents with sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing or lying down. It does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esophageal perforation, often associated with severe vomiting and alcohol consumption, can present with chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema, and is a medical emergency.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child brought to OPD with complaints of fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull revealed multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils as in the image below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for S100, CD1a. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

The above history along with the histopathological image showing Langerhans cells (image A), CD1a and positive S100 positive, is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Rosai Dorfman disease: Rosai Dorfman disease doesn’t show histiocytes. It presents with painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Kimura disease: Kimura disease presents with painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Juvenile Xanthogranuloma: Juvenile Xanthogranuloma shows multinucleated giant cells. It presents with papular lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is identified by a combination of clinical symptoms (such as bone pain, fever, and rash), characteristic histopathological features (nuclear grooves, eosinophils), and positive immunohistochemical markers (S100, CD1a). The presence of multiple lytic bone lesions, especially in the skull, is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child had fracture of humerus 2 years back. Now he’s having difficulty in hanging his school bag. There is also a presence of the shown deformity. What can be the most likely injury? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

  • The deformity seen in the image associated with supracondylar fracture of the humerus is commonly referred to as a "Gunstock deformity" or cubitus varus.
  • This deformity occurs due to malunion of the fracture, where the distal fragment of the humerus heals in a position that causes the elbow to angle inward toward the body.
  • The name "gunstock" comes from the appearance resembling the shape of a rifle's butt.
  • The anatomical distortion results from an improper alignment of the fracture during healing, often due to inadequate reduction or stabilization at the time of initial treatment.
  • This leads to a visible and functional deformity where the extended arm appears deviated towards the midline of the body, affecting the natural alignment and motion of the elbow.
  • This can also impact the arm's functionality, such as difficulty in activities that require extending the arm fully or placing load on it, like hanging a school bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Lateral Condyle Humerus Fracture: Often involves the growth plate and can lead to deformity if not properly treated. The most common sequela of non-union with displacement of this fracture is the development of progressive cubitus valgus deformity. Cubitus varus is the reported complication following lateral condyle fracture malunion after surgical intervention.

 

 

Option. B. Olecranon Fracture: Typically impacts elbow extension and would not generally cause problems with shoulder or arm suspension like hanging a bag. If the fracture is displaced there may be marked deformity at the elbow with a palpable gap. The hallmark of an olecranon fracture is the inability to extend the elbow against gravity. 

 

Option. D. Posterior Dislocation of Elbow: Would cause more immediate and severe movement restrictions and is less likely to present with delayed symptoms related to hanging a bag.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gunstock deformity or cubitus varus is seen in children with history of supracondylar fracture humerus.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

 

If the height for age of a child is less than -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population, it is most likely due to chronic malnutrition.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Malnutrition (Stunting): Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, occurs when a child does not receive adequate nutrition over a prolonged period, especially during the critical first 1,000 days of life (from conception to the child's second birthday). This results in impaired linear growth, making the child shorter than expected for their age. Height for age is the key indicator used to measure stunting.
  • Acute Malnutrition (Wasting): Acute malnutrition, or wasting, is characterized by a rapid loss of weight relative to height. It is usually the result of a recent illness or severe food shortage. Weight for height is the primary measure of wasting, not height for age.
  • Recent Infection: While a recent infection can temporarily affect a child's weight or growth velocity, it does not typically lead to chronic stunting unless the child experiences recurrent infections over a long period.
  • No Malnutrition: If a child's height for age is within the normal range, it indicates adequate nutrition and growth. However, a height for age < -2SD indicates a significant deviation from the norm due to chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute malnutrition: This condition affects the weight for height parameter, indicating a rapid loss of weight rather than a prolonged deficit in linear growth.

 

Option C. Recent infection: Although a recent infection can cause temporary weight loss or affect growth velocity, it is unlikely to result in stunted growth unless the child has had recurrent infections over an extended period.

 

Option D. No malnutrition: A child with a height for age < -2SD cannot be classified as having no malnutrition, as this deviation indicates chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vit B12

 

Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for DNA synthesis and plays a role in the conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to its active form. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to the functional deficiency of folate because it impairs the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl tetrahydrofolate, leading to the accumulation of the latter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: Folic acid, also known as vitamin B9, is a crucial vitamin required for DNA synthesis, cell division, and various metabolic processes. In cases of folic acid deficiency, methyl tetrahydrofolate can accumulate, but there is no direct deficiency of vitamin B12. Folic acid deficiency primarily affects folate-dependent reactions.

 

Option C. Vit B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not directly related to the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate. It primarily plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism as a cofactor for enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle.

 

Option D. Vit B6: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is involved in various enzymatic reactions, including those related to amino acid metabolism. It is not directly associated with the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 536

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-rebreathing mask

 

  • FiO2 Delivery: A non-rebreathing mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. This mask has a reservoir bag that fills with oxygen and a one-way valve that prevents the exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring a higher concentration of oxygen is inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: The Venturi mask delivers a precise FiO2, which can range from 24% to 66%, depending on the entrainment device used. It is often used in patients who require a specific oxygen concentration.

 

Option B. Hudson mask: This option appears to refer to a simple face mask, which can deliver up to 60% FiO2 at 10 L/min. It is less efficient in delivering high concentrations of oxygen compared to a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Option D. Nasal cannula: A nasal cannula typically delivers up to 44% FiO2 at a flow rate of 6 L/min. It is comfortable and used for patients who need low to moderate oxygen supplementation but cannot deliver the high concentrations achievable with a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask delivers the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy, capable of providing up to 80% FiO2 at flow rates of 10-15 L/min, making it suitable for patients requiring high concentrations of oxygen.

choices.text: Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

questions.text: What is the cause of the condition given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

 

The above image shows washerwoman's feet/ washerwoman's skin. It is seen in a case of immersion in water (both antemortem as well as postmortem drowning). It denotes skin maceration or swelling and wrinkling of the skin due to water absorption. Following changes are seen in washerwoman skin:

 

  • Wrinkling: After 3 hrs of immersion
  • Soddening (filled with water): After 12 hrs of immersion
  • Bleaching (whitening): After 36 hrs of immersion
  • Peeling: after 72 hrs of immersion

 

In the image, bleaching can be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic neuropathy: Diabetic neuropathy typically presents with sensory deficits, pain, or ulcers but does not cause the skin changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Hanging: Hanging does not cause the specific wrinkling and bleaching of the skin seen in the image.

 

Option D. Burns of foot: Burns would result in charring, blistering, and other thermal injuries, not the wrinkling and bleaching seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's feet (or skin) is characterized by swelling, wrinkling, and bleaching due to prolonged immersion in water, typically observed after more than 36 hours.

choices.text: Temp > 100.4°F occurring 48h after delivery
Temp > 100.4°F occurring 24h after delivery
Temp > 100.4°F occurring 12h after delivery
Temp > 100.4°F occurring 6h after delivery

questions.text: Puerperal pyrexia is defined as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Temp > 100.4°F occurring 24h after delivery

 

Puerperal pyrexia, also known as postpartum fever, is defined as a maternal temperature exceeding 100.4°F (38°C) after the first 24 hours postpartum. The initial 24-hour period following delivery is not considered because any fever during this time can be a reaction to the stress of labor and delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Puerperal pyrexia is defined as a temperature greater than 100.4°F occurring 24 hours after delivery, indicating postpartum infection or other complications.

choices.text: It is a type of droplet infection
Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease
Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.text: All of the following are TRUE about Rubella infection, EXCEPT? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease

 

Rubella infection in the 1st trimester: 90% have a significant risk for abortion and severe congenital malformations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a type of droplet infection:  This statement is true. Rubella is transmitted via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vertical transmission is possible:  This statement is true. Rubella can be transmitted from the mother to the fetus.

 

Option D. Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness:  This statement is true. While the risk of severe congenital malformations is lower in late pregnancy, the fetus may still be affected, with deafness being a potential outcome.

 

Educational Objective :

 

RUBELLA

 

Cause → RNA Togavirus

 

IP → 14-21 Days

 

Source → Cases [No carriers - No Iceberg phenomenon]

 

Mode of Transmission → Resp. [Air droplets]

 

Period of Communicability → 1 week before rash ← SYMPTOMS → 1 week after rash

 

Vaccine → Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain [C/I in pregnancy]

 

1st priority group → Non pregnant Non Lactating Reproductive 15-49 yrs female [1st trimester]


Congenital Rubella Syndrome → CVD [PDA], Cataract, Sensory Neural Deafness

 

Most common and most dangerous time for transmission of Rubella from Mother to Child is First trimester

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with bleeding disorder, gives family history of her father and sister suffering from the same bleeding disorders. Which is the most likely disorder? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Willebrand disease

 

Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder that affects both males and females, and it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that males and females have an equal chance of inheriting the disorder from a parent, which is consistent with the family history provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilia A: This is a X-linked recessive disorder primarily affecting males; females are typically carriers unless under rare circumstances.

 

Option C. Christmas Disease (Hemophilia B): Similar to Hemophilia A, this condition is also X-linked recessive, predominantly affecting males.

 

Option D. Factor 12 Deficiency: This is a much rarer condition and usually does not lead to significant bleeding issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Willebrand disease is characterized by its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects both genders, making it the most likely diagnosis for a female patient with a family history of bleeding disorders involving both male and female family members.

choices.text: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Bronchogenic Carcinoma
Germ cell tumor

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

Thymoma is the most likely diagnosis for the clinical presentation of a mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a rare syndrome characterized by a selective failure of erythroid element production in the bone marrow but normal granulopoiesis and megakaryocytopoiesis.

 

The patients have normocytic normochromic anemia, with normal granulocyte and platelet counts. Reticulocytes are significantly reduced or absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma:

 

Association: While lymphomas can present as mediastinal masses and may cause cytopenias, they are not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic Carcinoma:

 

Association: Bronchogenic carcinoma typically presents with respiratory symptoms and does not have a known association with PRCA.

 

Option D. Germ cell tumor:

 

Association: Germ cell tumors can present as mediastinal masses but are not specifically linked to PRCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a patient with pure red cell aplasia. PRCA is characterized by a selective deficiency of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia with normal granulocyte and platelet counts, and is often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intussusception

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and the barium study are characteristic of intussusception.

 

INTUSSCUSCPTION

 

  • Age: 6-8 months most common
  • Can be seen in adults due to a lead point like polyp or carcinoma.
  • C/F: Painful red currant jelly stools.
  • Mc type: Ileocolic Intussusception.
  • Initial: USG

 

 

Target/ Donut/ Sandwich/ Pseudo-kidney sign

 

IOC/Gold standard: Barium most commonly done/Air/Saline enema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Volvulus: Typically presents with a massively dilated loop of bowel and may show a "whirl sign" on CT rather than the findings seen on this barium study.

 

Option C. Diverticulitis: Would show inflamed and sometimes perforated diverticula; barium would outline these pouches, not the pattern seen here.

 

Option D. Ulcerative colitis: Chronic inflammatory condition of the colon, typically demonstrates continuous colonic involvement with loss of haustra, mucosal edema, and ulceration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception in adults requires prompt diagnosis and often surgical intervention, especially when associated with a pathological lead point. The barium study is crucial for diagnosis, showing specific patterns like the "target" sign that aid in identifying this condition.

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects multiple systems, primarily the respiratory and digestive systems, due to a defect in the CFTR gene.

 

This is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, CF patients are more likely to experience hypokalemia due to the loss of electrolytes through sweat and the effects of contraction alkalosis.

 

Other Options:

 

The diagnosis and features of cystic fibrosis include:

 

Option A. Sweat chloride test chloride concentration of 70 mEq/L: The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing CF. A chloride concentration greater than 60 mEq/L is indicative of CF.

 

Option B. Increased immunoreactive trypsinogen level: Newborn screening for CF often includes measuring immunoreactive trypsinogen levels, which are elevated in CF patients.

 

Option D. Contraction alkalosis: CF patients can present with contraction alkalosis due to loss of water and sodium, and renal waste of potassium and hydrogen ions. This is similar to the effects seen in patients taking loop diuretics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

questions.text: Identify the crystal in a patient with urinary pH of 8.7: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple Phosphate

 

Normally, urinary pH typically ranges from 4.4 to 6.5, which is acidic.

 

Here, an alkaline urinary pH of 8.7 promotes the formation of certain types of crystals, particularly triple phosphate (struvite) and calcium phosphate crystals. The image provided shows typical "coffin-lid" shaped crystals, which are characteristic of triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) or struvite crystals.

 

Triple Phosphate crystals are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Ureaplasma urealyticum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium Oxalate : These crystals typically form in acidic urine and have different shapes, such as envelope or dumbbell shapes.

 

Option C. Cystine : These crystals also form in acidic urine and have a distinctive hexagonal shape.

 

Option D. Uric Acid : These crystals form in acidic urine and appear as rhomboid or rosette shapes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple phosphate (struvite) crystals are associated with alkaline urine and have a "coffin-lid" appearance. They are commonly seen in patients with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive organisms.

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16

 

Fingerprints begin to form between 12 to 16 weeks of intrauterine life. By this stage, the basic patterns of the ridges on the skin are established. The formation continues, and fingerprints are complete by approximately 24 weeks of intrauterine life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

The recommended course of action for a patient with a clean-cut injury who received their last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago is to administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid. This recommendation is based on the standard guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis in wound management.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of palms and soles. He was subsequently diagnosed to have lung cancer. Which of the following is responsible for hyperpigmentation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, a chronic smoker, presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles and was diagnosed with lung cancer. This clinical scenario suggests the presence of an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

In such cases, the excessive ACTH produced by the tumor can lead to Cushing's syndrome.

 

Additionally, ACTH has an intrinsic MSH (Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone) activity due to the shared precursor molecule, proopiomelanocortin (POMC). The MSH part within ACTH stimulates melanocytes, leading to increased melanin production and resulting in hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex. It does not play a role in causing hyperpigmentation in this context.

 

Option C. Neuropeptide Y: Neuropeptide Y is involved in various physiological processes, including regulation of appetite and stress responses, but not in causing hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Melanin: While melanin is the pigment responsible for skin color, its production is stimulated by MSH. Thus, MSH is the direct cause of increased melanin and subsequent hyperpigmentation in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ectopic ACTH production, such as with small cell lung cancer, hyperpigmentation occurs due to the MSH activity of ACTH, which stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma


Phacolytic glaucoma occurs when high intraocular pressure (IOP) is associated with a mature or hypermature cataract. The patient's right eye exhibits high IOP (50 mmHg), flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens, all of which are characteristic signs of phacolytic glaucoma. The leakage of lens material into the anterior chamber induces an inflammatory response, causing the observed clinical signs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: This condition typically features a shallow or flat anterior chamber, which contrasts with the described deep anterior chamber. Therefore, it is not consistent with the clinical findings of this patient.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: This is usually a unilateral condition characterized by chronic inflammation, heterochromia (differences in iris color), and low-grade inflammation. It does not typically present with such high IOP or a cataractous lens as the primary issue.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: This type of glaucoma occurs due to lens-induced angle closure and is associated with a shallow anterior chamber. The patient, however, has a deep anterior chamber, which rules out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

questions.text: NADPH is used in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fatty acid synthesis

 

NADPH is essential for fatty acid synthesis. During this process, NADPH provides reducing equivalents necessary for the conversion of acetyl-CoA into long-chain fatty acids. This reduction step is crucial for building the carbon chains that make up fatty acids, and NADPH acts as a reducing agent in this pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketone Synthesis: NADPH is not directly involved in ketone synthesis. Ketones are typically synthesized from fatty acids during a state of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: NADPH plays a role in gluconeogenesis, which is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors. NADPH is required for certain enzymatic reactions in this pathway, such as the reduction of oxaloacetate to malate.

 

Option D. Glycolysis: NADPH is not directly involved in glycolysis. Glycolysis primarily uses NAD+ (Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide) rather than NADPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NADPH generating reactions

 

  1. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (Glucose-6-phosphate → 6-phospho-glucono lactone)
  2. 6-phospho gluconate dehydrogenase in the shunt pathway (6-phospho gluconate → 3-keto-6-phospho gluconate)
  3. Cytoplasmic isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Malic enzyme (malate to pyruvate).

 

NADPH utilizing reactions

 

  1. Ketoacyl-ACP dehydrogenase (Beta-ketoacyl-ACP → beta hydroxy acyl ACP) (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 4)
  2. Alpha, beta unsaturated acyl ACP → Acyl ACP (De novo synthesis of fatty acid - Step 6)
  3. HMG CoA reductase (HMG CoA → mevalonate (Cholesterol synthesis)
  4. Met-hemoglobin → Hemoglobin
  5. Folate reductase (Folate → dihydrofolate → tetrahydrofolate)
  6. Phenyl alanine hydroxylase (Phenylalanine → tyrosine)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hofmann’s degradation? FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cisatracurium

 

Explanation:

 

Cisatracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, which is a temperature and pH-dependent process that does not require enzymatic activity for metabolism. This makes it particularly useful for patients with certain types of organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mivacurium: It is a short-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily broken down by plasma cholinesterase and does not significantly undergo Hofmann elimination.

 

Option C. Pancuronium: This is a long-acting neuromuscular blocking agent that is primarily metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys, and it does not undergo Hofmann elimination.

 

Option D. Vecuronium: Like pancuronium, it is also metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys and does not undergo Hofmann degradation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisatracurium is unique among the non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents for undergoing Hofmann elimination, a process that allows safe use in patients with hepatic and renal insufficiency.

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

All of the above statements are true regarding keratosis obturans.

 

  • Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerves may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • Presenting symptoms may be pain in the ear, hearing loss, tinnitus and sometimes ear discharge. It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • On examination, the ear canal may be full of pearly white mass of keratin material disposed in several layers. Removal of this mass may show widening of bony meatus with ulceration and even granuloma formation.

 

 

Treatment

 

Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation, similar to the techniques employed for impacted wax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacteriophage

 

Transduction is a mechanism of genetic exchange in bacteria where DNA is transferred from one bacterium to another via a bacteriophage, a type of virus that infects bacteria. This process involves a phage accidentally incorporating bacterial DNA during the assembly phase within a previously infected host cell. When this phage infects another bacterium, it can introduce the previously acquired bacterial DNA into the new host's genome, facilitating genetic exchange.

 

Other methods of exchange of genetic material are:

 

  • Transformation involves the uptake of genetic material from the environment, which is released by other bacteria.
  • Conjugation is the direct transfer of DNA from one bacterial cell to another bacterial cell through a sex pilus or bridge. The transferred DNA is a plasmid, a circle of DNA that is distinct from the main bacterial chromosome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmids: Incorrect, as plasmids are involved in conjugation, not transduction. They are small, circular DNA molecules within bacteria that can replicate independently of chromosomal DNA.

 

Option B. Sex pili: Incorrect, sex pili are involved in conjugation, where they facilitate the direct transfer of DNA between bacterial cells.

 

Option D. Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria: Incorrect, this describes transformation, where bacteria take up DNA from their environment, not through a virus-mediated process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transduction facilitated by bacteriophages represents a crucial mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria, contributing to genetic diversity and the spread of traits such as antibiotic resistance among bacterial populations.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium amytal

 

Sodium amytal poisoning is known to cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination. This distinctive feature helps in identifying the presence of this substance in cases of poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxalic acid

 

  • Symptoms: Severe abdominal pain, vomiting, hypocalcemia, renal failure.
  • Postmortem Findings: Erosion and ulceration of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Soneryl

 

  • Description: A barbiturate used as a sedative-hypnotic.
  • Postmortem Findings: central nervous system depression.

 

Option D. Atomic number 33 (Arsenic)

 

  • Symptoms: Gastrointestinal distress, garlic-like odor on breath, multi-system organ failure.
  • Postmortem Findings: Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on postmortem examination is a characteristic finding in sodium amytal and copper sulphate poisoning.

questions.text: A patient displaying lytic lesions on the skull is being considered for a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. What represents a distinctive discovery on electron microscopy among the following options? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While Langerhans cells are a type of histiocyte, the presence of histiocytes alone is not specific to LCH. The defining feature is the presence of Birbeck granules.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, especially in eosinophilic granuloma, but they are not a distinctive finding on electron microscopy.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be present in a variety of inflammatory or granulomatous conditions, but they are not specific to LCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a distinctive and pathognomonic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

questions.text: An adolescent male came with complaints of lesions all over the face and back, which were predominantly comedones. What is the most effective treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Systemic doxycycline

 

Acne vulgaris, particularly when it predominantly presents with comedones, is a common condition in adolescents. Comedones are the primary lesions in acne, which can progress to inflammatory lesions if not adequately managed. Systemic doxycycline is an effective treatment for moderate to severe acne, particularly when it involves both comedones and inflammatory lesions like papules and pustules. Doxycycline acts as an antibacterial and anti-inflammatory agent, which helps reduce the bacteria responsible for acne (Propionibacterium acnes) and the inflammation associated with acne lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Systemic isotretinoin: Isotretinoin is a powerful systemic retinoid used primarily for severe, nodular cystic acne. Since the question specifies comedones without mention of nodulocystic lesions, systemic isotretinoin is not the most appropriate first-line treatment for this case.

 

Option C. Topical Dapsone: Topical Dapsone is used in the treatment of acne, particularly in inflammatory lesions. However, it may not be as effective for widespread comedones over the face and back, and topical treatments may not be feasible for extensive cases.

 

Option D. Systemic Azithromycin: While azithromycin is an antibiotic that can be used in acne treatment, it is less commonly used compared to doxycycline and is not the first-line treatment for comedonal acne. Doxycycline is preferred due to its broader use and efficacy in managing both comedonal and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic doxycycline is the most effective treatment for moderate to severe acne that involves comedones and inflammatory lesions, particularly when the condition is extensive.

choices.text: Normal vaginal delivery
Forceps delivery

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Normal vaginal delivery:
    • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
    • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
    • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.

 

Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.

 

Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults
Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding the healing of leprosy if left untreated? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Among the given options, Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid is the most appropriate answer

 

The bacillus Mycobacterium leprae is the source of the chronic infectious granulomatous disease known as leprosy (Hansen's disease).

 

Clinically, leprosy can exhibit one or more of the following symptoms

 

  • Patches of hypopigmentation
  • Presence of thickened nerves, and
  • Partial or complete loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas (First sensory modality to be lost is Temperature (hot/cold differentiation).
  • The presence of acid-fast bacilli in nasal smears or the skin.

 

Leprosy symptoms vary depending on how an individual's immune system reacts to the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae. Spontaneous resolution can be seen in about 80–90% (NOT just 50% as given in Option B) of people after being exposed to bacteria.  The remaining patients get clinical leprosy. Indeterminate leprosy typically has hypopigmented, ill-defined lesions. 75 percent of those Indeterminate leprosy patients experience spontaneous remission.

 

Clinically, very few patients exhibit either lepromatous leprosy or tuberculoid leprosy. As a result, compared to patients with tuberculoid leprosy, more patients with indeterminate leprosy experience spontaneous remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No spontaneous remission is seen: Incorrect. Spontaneous remission can occur in leprosy, particularly in the indeterminate and sometimes in the tuberculoid forms due to the individual's immune response.

 

Note - Even in the absence of specific treatment, a majority (80-90%) of patients tend to get cured spontaneously.

 

Option B. Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure. Incorrect. While many individuals may be exposed to Mycobacterium leprae and not develop full-blown leprosy due to a robust immune response, the assertion that half of the cases resolve spontaneously is not accurate. A higher percentage may never progress to clinical disease.

 

Option C. Spontaneous remission in children is variable when compared to adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spontaneous remission occurs even in the absence of specific treatment in majority (almost 80-90%) of the patients, but when compared to adults, in children spontaneous cure is very much variable.
  • If left untreated, Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 28.7

Parks textbook of preventive & social medicine 26th edition Pg 359

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry vagina is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Metronidazole

 

This is the description of vaginal discharge caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

Salient features:

 

  • It is transmitted by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4-21 days.
  • It typically results in vaginal soreness, frequent urination, and a copious, frothy, yellow-green discharge in females with a pH > 4.5.

 

Diagnosis:

 

  1. Direct Immunofluorescent antibody staining – Most sensitive
  2. Wet mount – Motile flagella seen
  3. Culture - Feinberg-Whittington media

 

Treatment:

 

  • D.O.C. – Metronidazole (2 gm Oral)
  • An alternate dose is metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days.
  • Prophylaxis to all sexual partners.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin

  • Primary uses: It is an antibiotic used primarily to treat bacterial infections like chlamydia, respiratory tract infections, and certain types of skin infections. It's a drug of choice for chlamydia and can also be used in the treatment of gonorrhea (often in combination with ceftriaxone).

 

Option C. Doxycycline

  • Primary uses: It's an antibiotic that is frequently used to treat bacterial infections such as chlamydia, non-gonococcal urethritis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. It's also a drug of choice for Lyme disease and is used for the prophylaxis of malaria in certain regions.

 

Option D. Oral fluconazole

  • Primary uses: It's an antifungal drug that's used primarily to treat and prevent fungal infections, especially Candida infections. It's the drug of choice for vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection). It's also used for systemic candida infections, cryptococcal meningitis, and prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for Trichomoniasis, which presents with vaginal itching, green frothy discharge, and a "strawberry vagina" on examination, distinguishing it from bacterial and fungal causes of vaginal symptoms that would require different treatments.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Chapter 33, Page nos 33.35 and 33.36

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7463 Unique Key-Q3304541

choices.text: They act on extracellular receptors only
It transmits impulses from cytoplasm to nuclear receptor
Act both on intracellular and extracellular receptors

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding the secondary messenger? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mediate intracellular hormone response

 

Secondary messengers are molecules that relay signals received at receptors on the cell surface to target molecules inside the cell. When a hormone binds to its extracellular receptor, it triggers the production of secondary messengers inside the cell. These secondary messengers, such as cyclic AMP (cAMP), inositol triphosphate (IP3), and calcium ions, then activate protein kinases and other enzymes, leading to an intracellular response. This process is crucial for the amplification of the signal and the initiation of specific cellular activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They act on extracellular receptors only: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers do not act on receptors; they are produced inside the cell after the hormone binds to an extracellular receptor.

 

Option B. It transmits impulses from cytoplasm to nuclear receptor: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers activate protein kinases that may eventually affect nuclear processes, but the secondary messengers themselves do not directly transmit impulses to nuclear receptors.

 

Option D. Act both on intracellular and extracellular receptors: This is incorrect. Secondary messengers act within the cell and do not interact with extracellular receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary messengers mediate intracellular hormone responses by transmitting signals from cell surface receptors to target molecules within the cell, leading to a specific cellular response.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

 

Explanation:

 

This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.

 

Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.2 Hz: This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option B. 2 Hz: This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. 20 Hz: This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

 

 

PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

A subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a life-threatening condition characterized by bleeding into the space surrounding the brain, leading to sudden, severe headaches often described as the "worst headache of my life." This patient’s symptoms, including a severe headache of sudden onset, hypertension, and nuchal rigidity (neck stiffness), are classic signs of SAH.

 

The CT scan provided shows diffuse blood in the subarachnoid space, which is a hallmark of this condition. The presence of blood in the sulci, gyri, and ventricles, and the star-shaped appearance of the blood distribution on the CT scan (referred to as the "star of death" sign) further confirms this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cluster headache: Incorrect. While cluster headaches can be severe, they are typically unilateral and associated with autonomic symptoms such as tearing and nasal congestion, not nuchal rigidity or hypertension.

 

Option C. Encephalitis: Incorrect. Encephalitis can present with headache, fever, and altered mental status, but it does not typically cause nuchal rigidity or hypertension, and the CT findings would differ.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Incorrect. Meningitis can present with headache, fever, and nuchal rigidity, but it is usually accompanied by fever and altered mental status. The CT scan findings would show inflammation of the meninges rather than bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with sudden, severe headache, nuchal rigidity, and hypertension. CT scan shows blood in the subarachnoid space, appearing as a "star of death."

questions.text: What is the purpose of using the SCOFF protocol? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eating disorder

 

The SCOFF questionnaire seems highly effective as a screening instrument for detecting eating disorders.

 

SCOFF QUESTIONS

 

  1. Do you make yourself Sick because you feel uncomfortably full?
  2. Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
  3. Have you recently lost more than One stone in a 3-month period?
  4. Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?
  5. Would you say that Food dominates your life?

 

*One point for every “yes”; a score of ⩾2 indicates a likely case of anorexia nervosa or bulimia

choices.text: White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one does not indicate drowning prior to death:(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Washerwoman's hands and feet

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet just indicates that body was immersed in water. It does not specify whether the person died due to drowning or not. It occurs due to infiltration of water into the outer layers of the skin, which will occur irrespective whether the person died due to drowning or the body was thrown in water after death.

 

 

If a body is recovered from water, the there are two different kind of signs to look for:

 

  1. Signs of Antemortem Drowning: These will indicate that person died due to drowning.
  2. Signs of Immersion: These will only indicate that the body was in water.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning (in descending order of accuracy):

 

  • Grass or weeds tightly held in hands (cadaveric Spasm): Surest sign
  • Drowning Froth Over Mouth and Nose and in air passages: Second best sign
  • Emphysema Aquosum (overinflated lungs)
  • Presence of sand / mud etc. in respiratory passages especially in terminal part
  • Diatom test
  • Presence of water especially if mixed with mud / sand etc. in Stomach or intestines
  • Paltauff Haemorrhage (Subpleural Haemorrhage)
  • Gettler’s test

 

Signs of Immersion

 

  • Washerwoman’s hand / feet
  • Cutis anserina=goose skin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in stomach: This suggests that the person was alive when entering the water and swallowed water, indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils: This foam, often referred to as "drowning froth," is a strong indicator of antemortem drowning as it forms when water mixes with air and mucus in the airways.

 

Option D. Positive diatom test: The presence of diatoms in the organs indicates that the person inhaled water while still alive, allowing these microscopic algae to enter the bloodstream and be deposited in various tissues, thus confirming antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet indicate immersion in water but do not specify drowning as the cause of death, unlike other indicators such as water in the stomach, white leathery foam, and a positive diatom test, which strongly suggest antemortem drowning.

questions.text: A patient has diabetes with fasting level of 140 gm/dl and PP level of 200 gm/dl. The target HbA1c to be maintained is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 7.0

 

For patients with an established diagnosis of diabetes, the target HbA1c level to be maintained is less than 7.0%. HbA1c is a measure of the average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 months, and keeping it below 7.0% is considered good glycemic control for diabetic patients.

 

The given information indicates that the patient has diabetes, with a fasting blood glucose level of 140 gm/dl and a postprandial (PP) level of 200 gm/dl. These elevated glucose levels are characteristic of diabetes, and maintaining an HbA1c level below 7.0% is the recommended target to reduce the risk of diabetic complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with an established diagnosis of diabetes, the target HbA1c level to be maintained is less than 7.0% to achieve optimal glycemic control and reduce the risk of diabetic complications.

questions.text: What is the SI unit used to measure the brightness of light from a point source among the options provided? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Candela

 

The candela is the SI unit used to measure the brightness (luminous intensity) of a light source emitting light in a specific direction. It quantifies the amount of light emitted from a point source within a solid angle of one steradian.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lux: Usage: Measures illumination or illuminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light reaching a surface. One lux is equal to one lumen per square meter.

 

Option C. Lambert: Usage: Measures brightness or luminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light emitted by a surface. One lambert is equal to the luminance of a surface emitting or reflecting one lumen per square centimeter.

 

Option D. Lumen: Usage: Measures luminous flux.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the total amount of visible light emitted by a source. One lumen is the luminous flux emitted within a solid angle of one steradian by a point source with a luminous intensity of one candela.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The leading cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior urethral valve

 

This is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants. PUV is a congenital malformation found only in boys where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the posterior urethra, preventing normal urine outflow and leading to bladder outlet obstruction. The condition can lead to hydronephrosis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral atresia: This is a rare congenital anomaly where a segment of the urethra fails to canalize or develop. It leads to complete obstruction of the urethra, and while it does cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is less common than PUV in male children.

 

Option C. Anterior urethral valve: This is a rare congenital anomaly and is much less common than the posterior urethral valve. While it can cause obstruction, its prevalence and significance in causing bladder outlet obstruction in male children are far less than that of PUV.

 

Option D. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter within the bladder. It can cause obstruction of the ureter itself. They are not the leading cause in male children when compared to PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most frequent cause of bladder outflow obstruction in male children is the posterior urethral valve (PUV).
  • PUV is a membranous fold located in the posterior urethra, typically found just distal to the verumontanum. It is thought to occur due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane.
  • Urethral obstruction can cause dilation of the posterior urethral valve, bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to a keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound and potentially oligohydramnios.
  • If not detected prenatally, PUV may present postnatally as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension or and recurrent UTIs.
  • Left untreated, PUV may result in chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Diagnosis of PUV is typically based on the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

 

  • Clarithromycin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 system, which is involved in the metabolism of many drugs, including digoxin. By inhibiting the metabolism of digoxin, clarithromycin can lead to elevated levels of digoxin in the blood, increasing the risk for digoxin toxicity.
  • Clarithromycin also acts as an inhibitor of the P-glycoprotein and can precipitate Digoxin toxicity. P glycoproteins are drug efflux pumps in the intestine that lead to a decrease in the bioavailability of drugs. Digoxin is one of the drugs that utilizes this mechanism for its metabolism. Therefore, the drugs which inhibit the Pgp can lead to the increased plasma concentration of Digoxin and lead to its toxicity.
  • Other drugs that inhibit the Pgp include 
    • Amiodarone
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Itraconazole
    • Propafenone
    • Flecainide 
    • Quinidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium chloride: This medication primarily affects potassium levels and has no significant interaction with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is not known to significantly interact with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option D. Triamterene: This diuretic medication primarily affects sodium and potassium levels and is not known to have a significant impact on digoxin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

 

  1. It is called Shelter's tape.
  2. It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition.
  3. Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm is considered undernourished.
  4. It is useful mainly for frontline field workers.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

The tape shown in the image is known as Shakir's tape (not Shelter's tape). It is a tool primarily used to assess Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children aged 6-59 months by measuring the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): Shakir's tape is specifically designed to measure the MUAC, which is an important indicator of malnutrition. MUAC is a quick and reliable method for assessing malnutrition, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • MUAC Readings and Color Coding:
    • Red: Less than 11.5 cm, indicating severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
    • Yellow: 11.5 to 12.5 cm, indicating moderate malnutrition or risk of malnutrition.
    • Green: Greater than 12.5 cm, indicating a normal nutritional status.
  • Frontline Field Workers: The tape is especially useful for frontline field workers who are often responsible for screening large numbers of children in community settings. It is simple to use, does not require advanced training, and can quickly identify children who need nutritional intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option 1 (Shelter's tape): This is incorrect; the tape is correctly called Shakir's tape.

 

Option 3 (Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm): This range is not considered undernourished according to the color coding system used in Shakir's tape. A reading below 11.5 cm is considered severe acute malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shakir's tape is a tool used to assess severe acute malnutrition by measuring the mid-upper arm circumference, particularly useful for frontline field workers in resource-limited settings.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Banana sign on USG associated with? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spina bifida

 

Spina bifida is a type of neural tube defect / spinal dysraphism which can occur to varying degrees of severity. It is often considered the most common congenital CNS malformation.

 

Banana sign - Refers to the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis, which appears elongated and curved, resembling the shape of a banana.

 

Lemon sign - In prenatal ultrasound, when spina bifida is present, the base of the skull can appear abnormal and shaped like a lemon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where abdominal contents protrude into the umbilical cord. This condition is associated with various ultrasound findings, but not specifically with the Banana sign.

 

Option C. Down’s syndrome: Characterized by the presence of an extra chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), Down’s syndrome has associated ultrasound markers like increased nuchal translucency and absent nasal bone, but not the Banana sign.

 

Option D. Klinefelter syndrome: A genetic condition affecting males, characterized by an extra X chromosome (XXY). This condition is typically identified through genetic testing and is not associated with the Banana sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Banana sign" on ultrasound is specifically associated with spina bifida and represents the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis. It is a critical ultrasound finding suggestive of spina bifida and should be carefully evaluated alongside other signs such as the "Lemon sign," which depicts an abnormal skull shape resembling a lemon, also indicative of neural tube defects like spina bifida.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary PPH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Placenta previa

 

Explanation:

 

Placenta previa is not a cause of secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). It is primarily associated with antepartum hemorrhage (bleeding before delivery) and is a risk factor for primary PPH (occurring within the first 24 hours after childbirth).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Retained cotyledon: Retained cotyledon can lead to secondary PPH due to retained placental fragments, causing continued uterine bleeding.

 

Option B. Endometritis: Endometritis, an infection of the uterine lining, can cause secondary PPH by leading to inflammation and impaired uterine contraction.

 

Option C. Placental polyp: A placental polyp, which is retained placental tissue that forms a growth, can cause secondary PPH through persistent bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is a cause of antepartum hemorrhage and primary postpartum hemorrhage but not secondary postpartum hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 804, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition
